February 13, 1926
Chicago, Illinois
The Arts Club
Wrigley Bldg. 
Chicago, Ill. 
Gentlemen:
This will acknowledge receipt of the Bergamo Rug, number 47 in your recent exhibition, purchased from Mr. S. Kent Costikyan. You have my check for $200 as part payment for this and according to the arrangement with Mr. Pope, I agree to pay the balance of $350 on or before July 15, 1926.
I wish to express my appreciation to the Arts Club and to Mr. Pope for the convenient arrangement made in my behalf in the purchase of this rug.
I am sure I am one of a

Chicago Arts Club: -
Chicago, Ill.

Sincerely yours
Mrs. V.S. Kehvarian
Milwaukee, Wis.
P.O. Box 894

element_texts.text: Completed

HUBERT HUNSUCKER
LANDSCAPE ARCHITECT
CHAMPAIGN, ILLINOIS entire address struck through
406 N. Prairie
January 12, 1926
Will you please mail at once if possible a copy of the catalogue mentioned in this enclosed clipping? It is cut from the Chicago Tribune.
I shall be glad to make remittance. 
Most gratefully,
Helen Margaret Hunsucker
attached clipping
Arts Club Issues Invaluable Treatise on Oriental Rugs
The Arts Club of Chicago has published a catalogue of the superb collection of early oriental carpets which is now on exhibit in the clubrooms. The catalogue is more than a mere listing of beautiful carpets and their descriptions. It is a treatise on the art of rug weaving as one of the finest of the fine arts, a keen and accurate interpretations of a really little know art. 
Arthur Upham Pope, who assembled the exhibit from all over the world, wrote the essay which, he says in a foreword, is "addressed to those who have no special knowledge of carpets." After the catalogue itself there is a short but invaluable bibliography, with a critical estimate as well as a description of each volume. Connoisseurs have come great distances to see the remarkable exhibit--Mr. Tattersall is on his way from the Victoria and Albert museum of London, for instance--which is the finest that has ever been shown in the United States. By the publication of this catalogue the Arts Club of Chicago has proved its eminence in the matters of the arts in the country, for the catalogue is of such a nature as to be a volume of great importance rather than a mere catalogue.

221 HARVARD STREET
Brookline - Mass.
Chicago Art Club
Chicago.Ill.
Gentlemen,
An article in the New York Times of January 17th tells of an exhibit of Oriental rugs being held in your club house - and speaks also of a catalogue for the exhibition compiled by Mr. Pope. I would like to know the price of this catalogue, and if these rugs will be shown in other cities-?
Yours truly
(Mrs. John W.) F. de l. Sauborn
1-18-'26

element_texts.text: Completed

DR. A CLIFFORD MERCER
324 MONTGOMERY ST
SYRACUSE NY
Jany 18, 1926
xChicago Arts Club
xChicago, Ill.
Dear Sirs:
As one who is very fond of his own forty oriental rugs, the writer read Mr. Brock's article in yesterday's N.Y. Times with great interest, and immediately wished for a Catalogue of your exhibition of oriental rugs. May I ask you to be kind enough to send me a copy of the Catalogue? Any charges for he Catalogue, and postage, I'll gladly send to you if you will let me know how much to send. 
I wonder if there is a possibility of having the collection of rugs exhibited in Syracuse. If you think there is, please let me know whom to address for particulars. 
Very truly yours
A. Clifford Mercer
[[note in pencil: xAbove address on envelope caused this letter to be returned. Now have street address from unclear of our Museum 410 N. Michigan St. ]]

Yours very truly
A Clifford Mercer

Toledo, Ohio,
Jan. 20,1925.
Mr. Arthur Upham Pope
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Sir:
I have just read in the Sunday, Jan. 17, "New York Times" of a catalogue you have gotten out on Oriental rugs now on exhibition at the Chicago Art Club. I am very desirous of owning the catalogue. Will you please let me know it's price so that I may forward the amount for one?
My home is n Mexico, but I will be here for some weeks and there will be time to receive one if you will kindly answer me at once -
Thanking you for your courtesy, I am
Very truly,
Bessie Kirkland Johnson (Mrs. G.W.)
2456 Glenwood Ave.,
Toledo, Ohio.

h. kurdian
IMPORTER OF
Antique Oriental Rugs and Carpets
1308 E. Douglas Ave.
WICHITA, KANSAS
Jan 26,
Art Club of Chicago
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Sirs:-
I would like to have a copy of A.U. Pope's catalogue of a loan exhibition of Oriental carpets, the Art Club of Chicago 1926 #30 Altman & Co. loan.
I am sending, under separate cover a copy of my latest publication ("The Dragon in Oriental Rugs,) which is one of a limited edition of 125, which are printed only for museums and libraries.
If you will trade me a catalogue for my book I will appreciate it very much. 
Yours very truly
H. Kurdian

New York City.
July 12th.
Five hundred and seventy five
West End Avenue
Miss Alice Roullier-
Chairman Exhibition Committee-
Arts Club- Chicago-
My dear Miss Roullier-
I am writing to you in regard to an exhibition of my pictures and etchings at the Arts Club in Chicago during the early winter. I am enclosing, under separate cover, the catalogue of my exhibition in New York. so that you may

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

gain some idea of what it is about. Much to my surprise the exhibition was very successful, a third of the pictures being sold--I am totally unknown in America--or was until then--and I have no money nor influence to speak of--this was my first exhibition--I would have written, asking for an interview before you sailed--only I was scheduled to sail

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

for China in August-but owning to the present disturbances-I will be in America this winter-
Each time I have opened my exhibitions-I have lectured on China - and just now that might be a point of interest-I have also written to Mr. Berthold Lauffur--whom I knew very well in China--asking for his co-operation should I have the opportunity of showing them in Chicago - The pictures are pastels - about 24 x 28 inches--and there are now some eighteen etchings - I will appreciate very much if you will take them under consideration and grant me an interview on your return, for of course you can form no opinion without seeing them. I can then show you what the critics had to say of them - 
Thanking you for your kindness in answering --
Sincerely
Lucille Douglas

RITZ CARLTON HOTEL
MONTREAL 
September 25th
My dear Miss Roullier-
I am leaving Montreal Saturday night, arriving in Chicago Sunday evening- I hope that you will have time to see me some time on Monday. I will call you up in the morning and you can tell me if you can arrange an appointment. Montreal has been? very appreciative.
Yours sincerely-
Lucille Douglass.

CABLE ADDRESS."GOTHAM NEW YORK"   TELEPHONE 2200 CIRCLE
HOTEL GOTHAM
FIFTH AVENUE AT FIFTY-FIFTH STREET
NEW YORK
WETHERBEE & WOOD, PROPR'S.
DECEMBER 17TH.
My dear Miss Roullier-
I am sorry not to have seen you again before I left Chicago - but I had such a ghastly cold that last month - and you were so busy. There were some details about the exhibition at the Arts Club which I wished to discuss with you. You said it would be arranged for March, when I asked you about the lecture at the Institute - Can you give me a definite date in March? I have invitations for other exhibitions an I do not want to crowd

element_texts.text: Completed

the time - Then as to placing - they will be in the large gallery, will they not -- for if they were placed in the corridor, people passing would brush the pastel off - I hope that you can let me know an early answer, as I have got to decide about the other places - arranging for time to ship them in  unclear.-
I hope that your Christmas will be a very happy one -
Yours sincerely-
Lucille Doublass.
cf. Anderson Galleries
489 Park Avenue.
P.S. I also would like to know if the Club attends to the advance publicity or am I responsible for that? 
L-D.

New York City-
January 11th-
My dear Miss Roullier-
I am sorry that my absence from town has caused  my reply to your very nice letter to be delayed - The dates given for the exhibition suit me admirably - as I am having an exhibition in Palm Beach the last week in January - then Miami and it gives me ample time to get the

element_texts.text: Completed

pictures back to Chicago by the first part of the last week in February - I think it will be wiser to put glass over them - I cannot tell you how very much I appreciate your kindness and I find it a great privilege to show my work at the Arts Club. Any arrangements which you may make in regard to publicity or percentage will be all right with me. I sincerely hope that things will not be so hectic next time I come to Chicago - for we may have the chance to see something of each other. 
With best wishes -
Yours sincerely
Lucille Douglass.
489 Park Ave.
9-Anderson Galleries
N.Y.C.

element_texts.text: Completed

[[note in pencil: 28th latest to receive pictures list 27th, N.L. unclear
149 West 14th St.
NEW YORK
Miss Alice Roulller.
701, Fine Arts Bldg.
Chicago, Ill.
Dear Miss Roullier:
Thanks ever so much for your letter. This show is the happiest and most exciting prospect that has happened to me in several years--and I wish I could adequately express my gratitude to you for your kindness in arranging it for me. 
I am working on some things now, several of which I wish to send, so did not expect to have my list of titles ready to mail for another week or so. But in the meantime, I would like to ask your opinion about some other pictures which I did not know whether or not to include in the list. There are perhaps 7 or 8 drawings distributed among half a dozen owners in Chicago, including the Art Institute, and Ben Hecht in New York which I would like to include. Would it be proper or "good policy" or all that sort of thing to ask these people to loan them for this show? Of course, if you think not, I can

Caption-Abstract: Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.
Use the link to the finding aid for a fuller description of collection contents that explains the use of the name and subject terms appearing in this catalog record.

element_texts.text: Completed

easily furnish the forty drawings you mention without them. 
Also, when I come to send the pictures should I send them all framed (and glassed); or all unframed, in mats only; or only the odd-sized ones in frames (I have about 12 of that kind--all the rest are in four regular-sized mats--12X15, 14X18, 18X22 & 22X28)? I have almost exactly forty frames, so could easily send the whole lot framed. 
If, after hearing from you, I get my list to you by Apr. 20, that will give you sufficient time for the catalogue, will it not? 
With kindest regards, I am
Very sincerely yours
Bertram Elliott

element_texts.text: Completed

149 W. 14th St
NEW YORK
Apr. 21/26
Dear Miss Roullier:
Here is the list, and I hope it's not too late. I have waited several days before making it out hoping to hear from you in regard to the advisability of including the privately owned pictures. 
As you see I have made out a list of forty pictures without them. But if you think they should be included--would it be troubling you too much to ask you to phone the various people for their permission? - or I could write to each of them immediately I had word word from you.
I will be packing the pictures in a few days, and unless I hear from you that you wish them sent framed, I shall send them in mats only. 
May I add that when the pictures arrive, I am hoping that there will be one among them that you will like well enough yourself to accept it as a slight tangible token of my appreciation of your kindness and trouble on my behalf.
Sincerely
Bert Elliott

element_texts.text: Completed

note in pencil; Read
149 W. 14th St.
NEW YORK
Apr. 22/26
Dear Mrs Carpenter:
I'm immensely thrilled at the prospect of my show at the Arts Club,--the one thing I most hoped for, some day, all the time I was in Chicago. 
In selecting a list of my forty best drawings I felt that several which belonged to different people in Chicago should be included. I have just now heard from Miss Roullier to "borrow these if possible." Therefore, since I think the "Car Couple" drawing you have certainly belongs among the forty, if you could be so generous as to loan it for the exhibition I would be exceedingly pleased. And in that case I wonder if I might trouble you to notify Miss Roullier so she can include its title in the catalogue, which goes to the printer on Tuesday. 
Thanking you in advance, and with the deepest gratitude for the part I know you must have taken in arranging this show for me--and with kindest regards to yourself, I am
Very sincerely
Bertram Elliott

element_texts.text: Completed

149 W. 14th St.
NEW YORK
Apr. 22/26
Dear Miss Roullier:
Since receiving your wire this noon I have written, in addition to Mr. Brewster, (whose letter I am troubling you to forward since I haven't his address) asking him for the loan of "Fullerton Orchestra (my No. 36, alternative); to Mr. Allerton, asking for "Eminent Journalist (No. 27); to Mrs. Carpenter, asking for "Car Couple" (No. 34); to Edgar Miller, asking for "Spain House Room"'; to Llewellyn Jones, asking for "The Traveling Dune"; to Harold Finder, asking for "Clark Street" (No. 37), "Rooster Man" (No. 38), "Band Concert in Oshkosh" (No. 39), and perhaps a nude; and to Pascal Covici, asking for a nude.
I am mailing all these letters to-night, Special Delivery, and asking each person to notify you immediately whether or not they can loan the pictures, so I think you should hear from them in time. In each case where one of the pictures will be loaned I think it is as good as, and in most cases better than, the picture I am sending,

Hastily and sincerely
Bertram Elliott

element_texts.text: Completed

149 W. 14th St.
NEW YORK
Apr. 26/26
Dear Miss Roullier:
The pictures are being packed and will be shipped this afternoon, so should be in Chicago Wednesday morning.
If you have not already given the list of titles to the printer there are several changes I would like to have made:
No. 34 - I have sent "Campers Feeding instead of "Car Sleeper."
No. 10, or 13 - I have sent a recent watercolor "Spring on the Palisades" which I would like to substitute for "Sunshine" (13) if L.L. Jones does not loan his "Traveling Dune"--or for "Sheridan Road (10) if he does.
Having used all my frames I am sending three drawings, Nos. 27, 33, and a nude, unframed. All three being alternatives to loans they may not need to be framed, but if you do use any of them I trusted that there would be enough loan pictures to release enough frames to accomodate them.
It may not be possible, but I wish that the printing of the list could be postponed until after the pictures have reached Chicago, so that with them and whatever loans you have obtained

element_texts.text: Completed

before you, you might make the final selection and revision of the list. Somehow I am doubtful of my judgment in regard to my own pictures, especially since while selecting I was trying to think not only from the purely artistic, but also from the exhibition and sales, standpoints--which latter I am not too sure of.
You might notice that I have sent very few recent things. This for several reasons. In the first place, because of various difficulties, economic and otherwise, my past year has been rather unproductive. Then the few good things I have done recently I felt were more suitable for two exhibitions (Salons of America and Whitney Studio Club) which I wish to take part in--and which also come in May. And finally I decided that even though they might not be better, at least my Chicago pictures would be more interesting to Chicago people than these others, which are mostly of distinctly New York subjects.
I happen to be rather short of cash at the moment, so I told the packers to include their charge on the shipping bill to the Arts Club--but to send me a duplicate, so I can repay it to you later. Or in case of any sales at the exhibition, you could deduct the amount from what you would otherwise send me. 
In regard to the enclosed list of prices--tentative prices--I again would be grateful to submit it to your judgment. In cases where you think you should or could get more, of course I would be delighted. But where someone wants

to buy a drawing but cannot pay the price I have marked I would really prefer to sacrifice the price than keep the picture--I'm so tired of some of those old drawings I really want to get rid of them.
I wondered if the enclosed "blurb" by Ben Hecht could be used in publicity to any advantage. Might I trouble you to return it, as it is the only copy I have?
--I hope I haven't "slipped up" on anything! With best wishes for the success of the show, I am
Very gratefully
Bertram Elliott

element_texts.text: Completed

July 10 - 1926
Dear Miss Kemp - I have finally arranged about the water-colors - a number of the artists were worried about prices because the franc has dropped so low & their things have been gone a long time - I have told them that we would remit on the basis of 29 francs to the dollar which was about the rate at the end of May & this is satisfactory to them - Inasmuch as we figured the prices at 25 to the $ and in some cases added a little more we will easily make our expenses & some profit too--
Please return all unsold watercolors with the exception of those by
Pruna
Survage
Fereat
to
Mr. H.P. Roché
99 Boulevard Arago
Paris, France
Prepaid
The work of the three men mentioned above please keep at Arts Club until

2
you see me in September = Please remit total sum of all sales, by draft, in name of Henri Pierre Roché & he will see that each artist gets what is coming to him = The prices in francs listed us were net. Also send him careful report of sales list. In the case of the large Pruna pastel which was under consideration by Mr. McKee for the Print Dept. of the Art Institute we are to take off 1/3 of the net price to us in paying artist for it = all other Prunas are to be treated like the rest of the artists. Please make remittance as rapidly as possible. I shall be writing you again soon

about other things = 
I hope you were able to straighten out the matter about which you cabled - I have no idea what it can be - such a terrific amount of money for carriage - We surely never contracted for anything like that with anyone - Hope my cable reached you promptly I answered P.D.Q. Write me about it when you have a moment also let me know if we got our big check for rug commissions & also if the Executive Committee voted to put some of our money into our purchasing fund.
I hope you are having a nice summer in Chicago, here we have had a very rainy season

element_texts.text: Completed

THE ART INSTITUTE OF CHICAGO
POTTER PALMER, PRESIDENT
ROBERT ALLERTON, VICE-PRESIDENT
CYRUS MCCORMICK, JR., VICE-PRESIDENT
ERNEST. A. HAMILL, TREASURER
ROBERT B. HARSHE, DIRECTOR
CHARLES H. BURKHOLDER, SECRETARY
MARTIN A. RYERSON, HON. PRESIDENT
FRANK G. LOGAN, HON. VICE-PRESIDENT
WILLIAM O. GOODMAN, HON. VICE-PRESIDENT
TELEPHONE CENTRAL 7080
Sept. 24th 1926
The Arts Club
Wrigley Building
Chicago, Ill
Gentlemen,
Enclosed please find our cheque for $364.50 in payment of the following pictures sold from your exhibition of modern French watercolors. 
La Fenetre by Hermine David
Prairie et Village by Flannnick?
Le Livre Bleu  Helene Perdriat

Les Lavandiers

Tête   Foujita
La Banque by unclear
Trusting that you will find this to be in order, I am
Yours very truly
unclear

element_texts.text: Completed

HOTEL SEVILLIA
117 WEST 58TH STREET
NEW YORK
Dear Mrs Kemp
I was so disgusted with myself for having lost, for such a ridiculous reason as influenza, the pleasure of being in Chicago these 2 weeks.
I have got up only to day. I hope everything has gone very well and I will be very grateful to you if you would write me as long and as nice a letter

element_texts.text: Completed

as you can, telling me all about! Impressions, attendency, sales, ecc.
My only consolation in my misery was to know that the Exhibition was under the protection of such an angel as you obviously are. 
Sending back the Exhibition will you please send also that brown leather suitcase that I left at the Club in the little room where were the painting we didnt show.
Thank you very much.

I dont know how to tell you my gratitude for all that you have done. Without you, I dont know what would have happen. I hope to see you soon sometime and continue such a deligtful acquaintance so suddenly interrupted. 
Thank you of everything thousand times
Hoping to hear soon from you.
Your sincerely
Lauro de Bosis
